title: Daters got woke in 2017
dc:creator: OkCupid
content:encoded:
Not only did the use of “woke” increase by 50%, but politics and social issues were also at the forefront of conversation this year

Sure, December is a time for loving (or loathing) the holidays — but it’s also a time for reflection, looking back on the year that’s passed and asking yourself “what the hell?” Because let’s be real: 2017 was insane — and many of the things that made it insane, from covfefe to North Korea, were hot topics on OkCupid.

When we reflect on the year gone by at OkCupid, we look to our users. What were they talking about in 2017? What became less important to them this year, and what became more so? To find out, we skimmed nearly 20 million user profiles to discover what they were writing about most in 2016 compared to 2017. And here’s the thing: despite a year riddled with bad news, 2017 produced some good news as well. Because we found that daters got woke in 2017. First of all, they got woke literally — though you (understandably) may be rolling your eyes that we’re actually using “woke” in a (somewhat?) scientific piece, use of woke in user profiles increased 50% this year. More importantly, however, they actually got woke: political terms, and words and phrases associated with social causes, saw an impressive increase in usage this year.

Politics

Politics were a hot topic of conversation between matches last year, but this year’s political mentions eclipsed those of 2016. Mentions of politics increased by over 26%, with usage of Republican increasing 28% and Democrat growing 38%.

Trump may be happy to know that his name’s appearance increased by 20%. It might be because he had everyone worried — nuclear increased by 33% and North Korea mentions rocketed (too soon?) by 63%. But covfefe was the political term, if you can call it that, with the greatest increase in mentions at 90%. Yes, this means that a handful of special daters — psychics, perhaps — wrote “covfefe” in their profiles before the infamous tweet.

Gender Equality

The Women’s March, #MeToo, the Silence Breakers — gender equality, or is often the case, inequality — has been a major topic of conversation this year, from international news to OkCupid profiles. After the Women’s March, we saw an increase in photos captioned “Women’s March,” and daters were increasingly more likely to state their views on gender issues in their profiles: from 2016 to 2017, feminist increased by 26%, nasty woman by 66%, and women’s rights by 73%. This is a trend we can definitely get behind, and we hope the conversation continues to grow — both online and off — in 2018.

TV Shows

OkCupid users got woke this year — but they’re human, so they also binged on Netflix, HBO and CW. Riverdale is a new show for 2017, so it’s no surprise that its usage skyrocketed (by 90%) now that the daters talking about it aren’t just those who live in the Bronx, love the Bronx, or have visited the Bronx. Stranger Things held onto some staying power with an increase of 54%, simultaneously knocking Game of Thrones down a notch — GoT still saw an increase in mentions, but by a meager 14%.

Celebrities

Celebs come and go, and then come back again. Take Clooney, for example: despite the fact that he hasn’t been crowned People’s Sexiest Man Alive since 2006, mentions of his name grew 18% whereas 2017’s Sexiest Man Alive, Blake Shelton, actually saw a decrease in mentions, dropping nearly 40%. Ouch. At least he can say he’s in good company: Jennifer Lawrence mentions fell 10%, Taylor Swift fell 19% and the Kardashian fam took a hit with 17% fewer mentions in 2017.

As far as the kings of comedy, Stephen Colbert stole the late-night crown from Fallon, who reigned in 2016 — mentions of Fallon dropped by over 50% whereas Colbert increased by nearly 30%. Kimmel remains in third place, but he nonetheless saw a small boost.

Dating

And now to the part we really care about: dating*. Dating has seen some shifts this year, and we say mostly for the better. Get ready to cue the awwws, because we saw love increase in mentions by 13%, which is a lot when you consider how frequently it was used last year, too. Devotion also increased by 13%, passion by 22%, and meaningful relationship by 25%. It probably warms our hearts most, though, that respect increased by 19% — a step in the right direction.

So what’s the takeaway?

Our consensus: turns out, 2017 really wasn’t so bad! Some bad things may have happened (yes, we’re talking about Trump), but the world kept turning and daters kept dating. And we found that, this year more than ever, daters were connecting over things that really mattered to them — like women’s rights, respect, and even George Clooney. In fact, nearly 90 million of these connections have been made in 2017 so far, so we’d definitely say it was a good year — at least a good year for love.

*Just kidding, we do really care about dating, but more importantly how dating relates to the things you care about most. You’ll see what we mean here.

Meet someone woke on OkCupid right now.

Written by Jane Reynolds. Illustrated by Dana Davis.

Daters got woke in 2017 was originally published in OkCupid Dating Blog on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.
